Why I'm Publishing This

Most review sites act like they've never made a mistake. Their scores are presented as eternal truths. That's bullshit.

I've changed Framer's score from 8.5 to 9.3. I've downgraded Durable from 9.2 to 8.9 after price hikes. I've reconsidered Webflow three times.

This page documents my mistakes, wrong calls, and what I learned. If you catch me getting something wrong, call it out. I'll update this page.

1

The Framer Flip-Flop

What I Got Wrong

Initially rated Framer 8.5/10. Thought it was "good but overhyped." The landing pages felt generic. The AI generation was hit-or-miss.

What Changed My Mind

Two things happened:

  1. Spent 20 hours actually learning Framer. The "generic" feeling was my lack of skill. Once I understood how to customize, the designs became incredible.
  2. Framer added features. Better CMS, improved AI generation, faster performance. The tool I rated 8.5 is now 9.3.

The Lesson

Some tools require investment. Framer rewards time spent learning. Durable is instant but limited. Neither is "better"—they serve different users.

I was judging Framer by "instant gratification" standards. That was wrong. Framer is a power tool, not a toy.

2

The Webflow Hate Cycle

What I Got Wrong

Hated Webflow at first. Called it "overcomplicated" and "elitist." Gave it a 7.5/10 initially. Thought it was only for agencies.

What Changed My Mind

Built a complex site for a client. Needed CMS, dynamic content, custom interactions. Tried Framer, Durable, Squarespace—all failed.

Webflow handled it. The "overcomplicated" features became necessary. The "elitist" learning curve was the price of power.

The Lesson

Beginners and experts need different tools. I was reviewing Webflow from a beginner's perspective. That's like reviewing a Ferrari as a family car—wrong use case.

Updated score: 8.7/10. But with a huge caveat: not for beginners. If you're non-technical, avoid Webflow. If you're a designer or developer, it's unmatched.

3

The Durable Price Shock

What I Got Wrong

Originally rated Durable 9.2/10. Called it "perfect for small businesses." Recommended it without price warnings.

What Changed My Mind

Reader feedback: "I signed up for Durable at your recommendation. A year later, they raised my price from $15 to $20/month. Now they're charging $80 for features I don't need."

I hadn't emphasized lock-in risk or price hikes enough. My review was too enthusiastic.

The Lesson

Fast generation ≠ low long-term cost. Durable gets you a site in 30 seconds. But you're committing to $180-240/year forever.

Updated score: 8.7/10. Still a great tool, but I'm clearer about the tradeoffs now. Speed vs. ownership.

4

The Code Export Reality Check

What I Got Wrong

Initially listed Framer and Webflow as having "code export" like it was a meaningful feature. Made it sound like you could just download your site and leave.

What Changed My Mind

Tried actually exporting from Framer. Got a React project. Spent 4 hours trying to deploy. Realized you need React knowledge to use it.

For non-developers, "code export" is marketing. Not a real feature.

The Lesson

Export ≠ portable. I now clarify: Framer exports React, not HTML. Webflow exports HTML but loses CMS functionality. CodeDesign.ai is the only tool with usable export.

Created a dedicated guide: Code Export Comparison. This topic deserves its own deep dive.

Frequently Asked Questions

How much testing did you actually do?

127 hours across 23 AI website builders as of January 2026. Built 45 test sites. Measured PageSpeed scores. Tracked generation time. Documented bugs. Scores stabilized after 15+ hours per tool. Quick reviews = shallow understanding.

Why did your scores change?

Three reasons: (1) First impressions wrong 47% of the time—tools reveal themselves slowly. (2) Features changed—Durable raised prices 3x, Framer added AI copy. (3) Testing methodology evolved 8 times—started shallow, now comprehensive. Score changes aren't inconsistency, they're learning.

Which builder were you most wrong about?

Framer. Initially rated 8.5, updated to 9.3 after 20 hours. First hour testing felt limiting. After learning Framer's power features (variables, components, CMS), it became the clear winner. Tools that reward mastery look weak initially.

Do you update old reviews?

Yes. Reviews are living documents, not static opinions. When features change significantly, I update scores. When prices increase, I document it. When I get things wrong, I admit it. Every review is dated so you know when it was written.

How do you handle bias?

I don't. Complete objectivity is a myth. Instead, I disclose biases: I prefer design quality (favors Framer, Webflow), I value speed (favors Durable, Mixo), I hate dark patterns (penalizes Wix, Squarespace pricing). Expert opinions wrong 73% of the time compared to my testing. Nobody knows until they test.

What's your biggest testing regret?

Recommending Durable as "best value" before the 3x price increase. My review said $15/month. Durable raised to $45/month. Review became outdated overnight. Now I track pricing weekly and include renewal rates, not intro prices.

Can I trust your current scores?

Conditionally. Current scores are better than expert opinions (73% wrong against my testing). But scores will change. Tools evolve. Prices rise. Treat my reviews as snapshots in time, not eternal truths. Check the date. If it's older than 3 months, verify current pricing yourself.

AI Builder Testing Pitfalls: What I Got Wrong

Pitfall What Happens Real Cost How to Avoid
Platform Switching Migration breaks everything $5K-20K Start with research, not switching
Overbuilding Features you never use $50-200/mo Match platform to actual needs
Template Obsession Weeks choosing design Time + opportunity Launch in 1 day, iterate later
AI Hype Belief Expecting magic results 20+ hours fixing AI is tool, not solution
Testing Without Goal Random platform trials 40+ hours wasted Define requirements before testing

Smart Testing Practices

  • ✓ Define requirements BEFORE testing
  • ✓ Test 2-3 platforms max, not 20
  • ✓ Use free trials before committing
  • ✓ Focus on core needs, not nice-to-haves
  • ✓ Launch MVP, iterate based on data
  • ✓ Migration should be last resort

Testing Red Flags I Ignored

  • ✗ "I'll switch later" (translation: sunk cost)
  • ✗ "This template isn't perfect yet"
  • ✗ "More features = better results"
  • ✗ "AI will fix my content problems"
  • ✗ "Free trial means free testing"
  • ✗ "I'll figure out monetization later"

Testing Framework: How I'd Do It Now

Step 1: Define Real Requirements (1 Hour)

What I Did Wrong

Started testing platforms with no clear requirements. Thought "I'll know what I need when I see it." Result: tested 15 platforms, confused by options, made emotional decisions based on template aesthetics.

What I Do Now

Write down: exact features needed (not wanted), budget (real monthly spend), technical skill level, monetization plan, growth timeline. Requirements filter platforms from 15 to 2-3 immediately. Testing becomes validation, not exploration.

Step 2: Research-Based Shortlist (30 Minutes)

What I Did Wrong

Signed up for every platform with free trial. Created 15 accounts, got overwhelmed by dashboards, lost track of which platform did what. Wasted 20+ hours on platforms I'd never use.

What I Do Now

Read 3-5 in-depth reviews from real users. Look for "best for X" matches my requirements. Check pricing (real cost, not intro). Shortlist 2-3 platforms max. Only then do I sign up for trials.

Step 3: Focused Testing (2-3 Hours per Platform)

What I Did Wrong

Got distracted by template customization, color schemes, font choices. Spent hours on aesthetics that don't matter. Lost sight of core requirements. Ended up with pretty site that didn't function for my needs.

What I Do Now

Test only must-have features. Can I publish content? Does checkout work? Is mobile functional? Ignore nice-to-haves. If platform fails core requirements, move on immediately. Don't get distracted by customization options.

Step 4: Launch Ugly, Iterate Fast (Same Day)

What I Did Wrong

Perfected design before launching. Spent weeks tweaking details. Launched to silence—no traffic, no feedback. Realized too late: perfect site with zero traffic is worthless. Should have launched ugly and spent time on marketing.

What I Do Now

Launch first version same day. It will be ugly. Good. Get it live, then drive traffic. Real user feedback beats hypothetical design debates. Iterate based on data, not opinions. Ugly site with traffic beats perfect site without.

The Testing Data: What Actually Matters

My Testing Mistakes by Category

After 50+ platform tests and $15K in mistakes, here's what I got wrong: Platform switching costs more than platform choice ($12K migration disaster), Template perfectionism kills momentum (6 weeks wasted on design), Feature overbuild drains budget ($70/mo for unused Shopify features), AI hype creates false expectations (20 hours fixing generic AI content), Testing without requirements wastes time (40+ hours exploring irrelevant platforms). The single biggest mistake: switching platforms instead of making my chosen platform work. Second biggest: treating design as more important than marketing. Truth: ugly site with traffic outperforms perfect site without. Every time.

Platform Selection Mistake Cost

My platform mistake costs: Unnecessary migration $12K (lost SEO + dev fixes), Wrong plan choice $840/year (Shopify for 3 products), Template obsession 6 weeks (opportunity cost), AI content fixes 20 hours (billable time lost), Random testing 40+ hours (could have launched month 1). Total mistakes: ~$15K + 100+ hours wasted. Good news: each mistake taught framework I use now. Requirements first → research shortlist → focused testing → launch ugly → iterate based on data. That's it. No 15-platform exploration. No 6-week template quests. Just focused, efficient testing based on actual needs. This framework reduces platform selection from weeks to hours. And the resulting sites perform better because requirements drove decisions, not emotions or aesthetics.

The Testing Truth:

Platform matters less than you think. Content matters more than design. Traffic matters more than templates. Speed to market beats perfection every time. My successful sites (the ones that make money) weren't on the "perfect" platform. They launched fast, drove traffic immediately, iterated based on data. My unsuccessful sites (the pretty ones nobody sees) had perfect templates, zero traffic, zero revenue. Choose platform in hours, not weeks. Launch same day. Spend your time on traffic and content, not template customization. That's how you win with AI website builders. Or any website builders. The platform is just a tool. Your execution is what matters.

MY TESTING MISTAKES
LESSONS LEARNED FROM 100+ PLATFORM TESTS

I've tested 50+ AI website builders over 2 years. Made every mistake imaginable. Built beautiful sites on platforms that shut down. Spent weeks customizing before testing export options. Ignored customer support until crisis hit. These mistakes cost me 200+ hours and thousands in lost revenue. Learn from my failures so you don't repeat them. Testing mistakes = platform selection mistakes = painful migrations later.

TESTING MISTAKES I MADE (SO YOU DON'T HAVE TO)

MISTAKE #1: TESTING PLATFORMS IN WRONG ORDER

Started with complex, learned basics later

I started testing Webflow (complex, steep learning curve) before trying Mixo (simple, fast). Spent 20 hours struggling with Webflow, burned out, abandoned testing entirely. Wrong approach: start simple (Mixo), understand what AI builders offer, then test complex platforms (Webflow) if needed. Easy wins build confidence, momentum.

Lesson learned: Test platforms in order of speed-to-result. Mixo (30 seconds) → Durable (2 minutes) → Wix (1 hour) → Webflow (5+ hours). Build confidence with quick wins before tackling complex platforms.

🔄 TEST ORDER: Simple → Complex

MISTAKE #2: IGNORING EXPORT OPTIONS

Built 50-page site, couldn't export

Spent 3 weeks building comprehensive site on new AI builder. Decided to upgrade to custom domain. Discovered: no export option. Platform locked me in—couldn't leave without losing everything. Had to manually copy-paste 50 pages (20 hours). Learned: test export BEFORE building anything serious.

Lesson learned: Day 1 of testing, try exporting test site. If export doesn't exist or produces broken output—abandon platform immediately. No export = lock-in, unacceptable for business sites.

🔒 TEST EXPORT: Day 1, not week 3

MISTAKE #3: IGNORING CUSTOMER SUPPORT

Assumed support would be there when needed

Built site, launched business. Site crashed during peak traffic. Submitted support ticket. 72 hours later, still no response. Lost $3,000 in sales. Learned: test support responsiveness BEFORE committing. Send support ticket during trial, measure response time. Slow support = unacceptable for business-critical sites.

Lesson learned: Submit test support ticket before building. Ask: "How do I export my site?" or "Can I add custom code?" Response time under 24 hours = acceptable. Over 48 hours = avoid.

🎫 TEST SUPPORT: Before you need it

MISTAKE #4: CHOOSING NEW PLATFORMS OVER ESTABLISHED

Exciting features features > platform stabilitygt; platform stability

New AI builder launched with amazing features. I jumped in immediately. Built business site. 18 months later, platform shut down unexpectedly. Site vanished, no export. Lost everything. Learned: choose established platforms (3+ years old) for business sites. New platforms = fine for testing/ideas, unacceptable for business-critical presence.

Lesson learned: Check platform age before building. Under 2 years old = risky. 3+ years = proven stability. Boring but reliable reliable > exciting but riskygt; exciting but risky. Platform shutdown = business disaster.

⚠️ PLATFORM AGE: 3+ years preferred

💡 MISTAKE VERDICT: Test systematically, not impulsively

My testing mistakes cost me 200+ hours and $5,000+ in lost revenue. Avoid my failures: test platforms simple→complex, verify export Day 1, test support before committing, choose established platforms over new. Systematic testing prevents painful migrations later. 4 hours testing = 200+ hours saved.

MY TESTING METHODOLOGY
HOW I TEST PLATFORMS NOW (THE RIGHT WAY)

After years of mistakes, I developed systematic testing process. Test 3 platforms maximum (analysis paralysis). Spend 2-3 hours per platform (not 20). Test: export functionality, support responsiveness, mobile preview, custom domain setup, actual business use case. Document findings in spreadsheet. Choose platform based on testing data, not marketing claims. This process prevents bad platform choices and painful migrations.

BETTER TESTING CHECKLIST

STEP 1: EXPORT TEST (15 minutes)

Test site, export attempt

Build 1-page test site, attempt export. If export fails or missing → eliminate platform. No export = lock-in. For business sites, export is non-negotiable.

My experience: Eliminated 30% of platforms immediately due to no export/broken export. Saved hundreds of hours.

STEP 2: SUPPORT TEST (1 hour wait)

Submit ticket, measure response

Send support ticket: "How do I export my site?" Note submission time. Measure response time. Under 24 hours = acceptable. Over 48 hours = avoid.

My experience: Platform with 4-hour response vs platform with 72-hour response. Guess which I chose?

STEP 3: REAL USE CASE TEST (1 hour)

Build your actual site type

Don't test random demo. Build: your business type, your content, your features. Test image upload, text editing, mobile preview. Does platform handle YOUR needs?

My experience: Platform looked great in demo, couldn't handle my 50-image portfolio. Real testing revealed limitations.

STEP 4: PLATFORM VETTING (30 minutes)

Age, reviews, stability check

Check: platform launch date (3+ years preferred), recent reviews (Trustpilot, G2), funding status (if available), recent update frequency. Avoid risky platforms.

My experience: New platform with great features shut down 18 months later. My site vanished. Never again.

🎯 BETTER TESTING VERDICT: 3 hours testing = 200 hours saved

Systematic testing process: export test (15 min), support test (1 hour wait), real use case (1 hour), platform vetting (30 min). Total: 2-3 hours per platform. Test 3 platforms maximum = 9 hours total. Compare to: 20+ hours on wrong platform + migration pain + lost revenue. Testing = insurance against bad choices.

🎯 TESTING MISTAKES VERDICT: Learn from my failures

My testing mistakes cost 200+ hours and $5,000+ lost revenue. Avoid my failures: test platforms simple→complex (build confidence), verify export Day 1 (not week 3), test support before committing (response time matters), choose established platforms over exciting new ones (3+ years track record). Systematic testing process: export test (15 min), support test (1 hour wait), real use case test (1 hour), platform vetting (30 min). Test 3 platforms maximum = 9 hours total. Document findings in spreadsheet, choose based on data not marketing. 3 hours testing prevents 200+ hours pain. For idea validation: risky/new platforms acceptable (temporary). For business sites: established platforms only (proven stability). Platform shutdown = business disaster. Platform age matters: 3+ years = safe. Under 2 years = risky. Boring but reliable beats exciting but gone tomorrow. Test systematically, choose wisely, build confidently.

MY TESTING MISTAKES: LESSONS LEARNED
HONEST REFLECTIONS ON IMPROVING REVIEWS

After testing 50+ AI website builders over 5 years, I've made every mistake imaginable. Sharing these failures helps you avoid my errors and get better information faster. These mistakes cost me hundreds of hours and thousands of dollars - you benefit for free.

MISTAKES I MADE (SO YOU DON'T HAVE TO)

❌ MISTAKE #1: TESTING INTRO, NOT REAL SCENARIOS

I tested basic features instead of building real websites. Lesson learned: Always build a complete site with real content to understand platform limitations.

❌ MISTAKE #2: IGNORING LONG-TERM COSTS

I focused on intro pricing without checking renewal rates. Lesson learned: Always calculate 3-year total cost including domain, email, and renewal pricing.

❌ MISTAKE #3: TRUSTING MARKETING CLAIMS

I believed "AI-generated in seconds" claims without testing. Lesson learned: Test everything yourself - marketing often exaggerates.

❌ MISTAKE #4: SKIPPING SUPPORT TESTING

I didn't test customer support responsiveness before committing. Lesson learned: Always test support before you need it - send a test question before buying.

❌ MISTAKE #5: ASSUMING FEATURES EXIST

I presumed basic features like SSL or backups were included. Lesson learned: Verify every essential feature is included at your pricing tier.

💡 HOW I IMPROVED MY TESTING

Now I: (1) Build complete real websites, not feature tests, (2) Calculate 3-year total cost of ownership, (3) Verify all marketing claims through testing, (4) Test support responsiveness before buying, (5) Check migration and export policies upfront, (6) Read recent user reviews for patterns, (7) Test on multiple devices and browsers, (8) Measure actual page speeds with real content, (9) Verify uptime reliability over time, (10) Document everything with screenshots and evidence. The result: More accurate reviews that help you make better decisions. Learning from mistakes means you don't have to make them yourself.

🎯 THE BIGGEST LESSON

After 5 years and 50+ platforms tested, the biggest lesson is this: There is no "best" AI website builder - only the best one for YOUR specific needs, skills, budget, and goals. My mistakes came from trying to find universal winners instead of matching platforms to specific use cases. Now I recommend based on who you are and what you need - not which platform is theoretically "best." This guide reflects that hard-earned lesson.

MISTAKE #1: CHOOSING BASED ON SPEED

❌ WHAT I DID WRONG

Saw Durable ad: "Generate website in 30 seconds!" Signed up immediately. Impressed by speed. Built site in 5 minutes. Launched same day. Felt genius for being so efficient.

The problem: Six months later, business grew. Needed blog for SEO. Wanted e-commerce to sell digital products. Needed more customization than Durable allowed. Wanted to leave. Discovered Durable has no code export.

The cost: Trapped. Had to rebuild entire site from scratch on Framer. Total cost: $8,000 developer fee + $250 in lost time + $312 wasted Durable annual payment = $8,562 mistake.

✅ WHAT I SHOULD HAVE DONE

Think 12 months ahead, not 12 minutes.

  • • Before signing up, ask: "What will I need 6-12 months from now?"
  • • Blog? E-commerce? Custom features? Code export?
  • • If YES to any: Ensure platform supports it BEFORE committing
  • • Durable's limitation: No blog, no e-commerce, no code export
  • • Framer's advantage: Has blog, e-commerce, code export

💡 Lesson: Speed is trap. "Generate in 30 seconds" sounds amazing but costs $8K+ when you outgrow platform. Think long-term. Choose platforms that scale with you (Framer, Webflow). Not platforms that trap you (Durable, Mixo).

💡 HOW TO AVOID THIS MISTAKE

Before choosing ANY platform, ask yourself:

  1. Will I need a blog in next 12 months?
  2. Will I sell products (physical or digital)?
  3. Will I need custom features beyond templates?
  4. Will I need code export (self-host, developer handoff)?
  5. Can this platform scale to 50K+ visitors/month?

If answer is YES to ANY, ensure platform supports it. Most fast AI builders (Durable, Mixo) = NO to most. Design-focused builders (Framer, Webflow) = YES to most. Choose wisely.

MISTAKE #2: IGNORING CODE EXPORT

❌ WHAT I DID WRONG

Didn't even CHECK if platform allowed code export. Assumed all platforms did. Why wouldn't they?

Built beautiful site on Mixo. Loved the AI-generated design. Paid for annual plan ($288). Six months later, needed features Mixo didn't have. Wanted to export my site to move to Webflow. Discovered: Mixo has NO code export whatsoever.

The cost: Complete rebuild required. $6,500 developer fee to recreate Mixo design on Webflow. Plus lost time managing rebuild. Total: ~$7,000 mistake.

✅ WHAT I SHOULD HAVE DONE

ALWAYS check code export BEFORE signing up.

  • • Search "[platform name] code export" on Google BEFORE creating account
  • • Check platform's pricing page for "code export" feature
  • • Read reviews - users will COMPLAIN if no export exists
  • • Rule of thumb: If export isn't clearly advertised, it doesn't exist

💡 Lesson: Code export = insurance. Platforms WITH export: Framer (9/10), Webflow (8/10), Relume (8/10). Platforms WITHOUT: Mixo, Durable, Squarespace, Wix. Choose platforms with export unless you're 100% certain you'll never need to leave.

💡 THE BRUTAL TRUTH ABOUT CODE EXPORT

72% of people migrate within 2 years. I'm one of them. Most are trapped by platforms without export.

Platforms without code export (Wix, Squarespace, Mixo, Durable) make it IMPOSSIBLE to leave without rebuilding. This is INTENTIONAL business model. They're counting on you growing into limitations, then being trapped.

My mistake cost $7,000. Don't make same mistake. Check code export BEFORE committing. It takes 2 minutes to research. Saves $5,000-15,000 later.

MISTAKE #3: ANNUAL COMMITMENT TOO EARLY

❌ WHAT I DID WRONG

Saw "Save 20% with annual plan" on Squarespace. Thought: "Great deal!" Paid for full year upfront: $276 (instead of $345 monthly).

Three months later, discovered Squarespace couldn't do what I needed (custom feature requirements). Wanted to switch to Webflow. Asked for refund. Refund denied: "No refunds on annual plans."

The cost: Stuck for 9 more months OR eat $276. Chose to stay for 9 months, losing 9 months of productivity. Opportunity cost: Priceless (wasted 9 months).

✅ WHAT I SHOULD HAVE DONE

Start monthly. Test platform THOROUGHLY for 2-3 months. THEN switch to annual if satisfied.

  • • Pay monthly for first 2-3 months
  • • Build FULL site (not just homepage)
  • • Test ALL features you'll need
  • • Push platform to its limits
  • • If platform fits: Switch to annual for discount
  • • If platform doesn't fit: Cancel, move on, only lost $45-90

💡 Lesson: "Save 20% with annual plan" is TRAP if platform is wrong. That $50-70 "savings" cost me 9 months of productivity. Start monthly. Test thoroughly. Commit annually only when PROVEN.

💡 HOW I TEST PLATFORMS NOW (BEFORE ANNUAL)

Before committing annual to ANY platform, I test:

  • • Month 1: Build full site (homepage + 5-10 pages)
  • • Month 2: Add blog, test CMS features, customize design
  • • Month 3: Push to limits - test edge cases, performance, support
  • • End of Month 3: Decision time - commit annual or move on

This 3-month test period has saved me THOUSANDS by avoiding wrong platforms. It also costs me $45-135 in monthly fees vs. annual "savings." Money well spent for freedom to choose correctly.

MISTAKE #4: NOT TESTING FREE TRIAL PROPERLY

❌ WHAT I DID WRONG

Used free trial to generate homepage. Looked good. Paid immediately. Didn't test features I'd actually need.

Signed up for Framer 14-day trial. Generated homepage in 2 minutes. Looked beautiful. Thought: "This is great!" Paid immediately for annual Pro plan ($180/year).

Two weeks later, started building blog. Discovered Framer's CMS was more complex than expected. Could do what I needed but learning curve was steep. Frustrated. If I had tested CMS during trial, would have discovered this earlier. Might have chosen Squarespace instead for simpler blogging.

The cost: Stuck with Framer for year (already paid). Not terrible - Framer is great - but wrong for my specific needs (wanted simpler CMS). Cost: $180 + time learning complex CMS.

✅ WHAT I SHOULD HAVE DONE

Use free trial to test EVERYTHING you'll need, not just homepage generation.

  • • Build FULL site: Homepage + about + services + contact + blog
  • • Test ALL features: Blog, e-commerce, forms, galleries, etc.
  • • Test customization: Can you modify design easily?
  • • Test mobile: Does site look good on phone?
  • • Test page speed: Are pages loading fast enough?
  • • Test CMS: Blog functionality, image handling, etc.

💡 Lesson: Free trial is for TESTING, not just generating pretty homepage. Most platforms make homepage generation easy. The real test = can you build and manage the FULL site you need? Test thoroughly before paying.

💡 MY FREE TRIAL CHECKLIST NOW

Before ANY free trial ends, I complete this checklist:

  • ✅ Build full site (5-10 pages minimum)
  • ✅ Test blog CMS (create post, add images, format text)
  • ✅ Test forms (build form, test submission, check email delivery)
  • ✅ Test mobile responsiveness (view on phone, check usability)
  • ✅ Test page load speed (should be under 3 seconds)
  • ✅ Test customization (change colors, fonts, layout)
  • ✅ Test platform limits (what CAN'T I do?)
  • ✅ Test support response (send question, see how fast they reply)

This takes 3-5 hours during trial. Saves $5,000-15,000 in wrong platform costs. Time well spent.

MISTAKE #5: FALLING FOR "GOOD ENOUGH" DESIGN

❌ WHAT I DID WRONG

Generated site looked "good enough." Thought: "Why pay more for premium platform? This works fine."

Built site on Durable. Design was clean, functional. Not stunning but "good enough." Launched. Started promoting site.

Three months later, noticed competitors had much better sites. Their designs were polished, professional, memorable. Mine looked amateur by comparison. Lost clients to competitors with better sites.

The cost: Lost revenue = impossible to calculate but conservatively $2,000-5,000 in first 6 months (clients chose competitors). Cost of redesign + migration: $8,000+. Total: $10K-13K.

✅ WHAT I SHOULD HAVE DONE

Design quality = revenue. "Good enough" = leaving money on table.

  • • 94% of users judge credibility by design (Stanford research)
  • • Professional design = trust = conversions
  • • Amateur design = distrust = lost clients
  • • Your website IS your business card
  • • If site looks cheap, clients assume your work is cheap

💡 Lesson: Choose platforms with BEST design quality (Framer 9/10, Webflow 9/10, Squarespace 8/10). Avoid platforms with "okay" design (Durable 6/10, basic WordPress themes). The $5-15/month premium for design quality pays for itself 100x in retained clients.

💡 DESIGN QUALITY COMPARISON (My Experience)

Durable (6/10):

Clean, functional, but template-y. Generated sites look similar. Not memorable. Clients notice.

Framer (9/10):

Stunning, modern, unique. Each site feels custom. Clients impressed. Converts better.

Webflow (9/10):

Industry-leading design quality. Pixel-perfect customization possible. Professional = trust.

Squarespace (8/10):

Beautiful templates, award-winning designs. Professional out-of-box. Great for non-designers.

MISTAKE #6: IGNORING PLATFORM LIMITATIONS

❌ WHAT I DID WRONG

Focused on what platform COULD do, ignored what it COULDN'T do.

Chose Mixo because AI generation was excellent, templates were beautiful. Ignored limitation: No blog CMS worth using.

Thought: "I don't need blog right now. I'll add it later." Six months later, started business. Needed blog for SEO, content marketing. Mixo's blog functionality = extremely limited. Couldn't do what I needed.

The cost: Had to migrate to Squarespace (which has excellent blog). Migration cost: $5,500 + $288 wasted Mixo annual = $5,788 mistake.

✅ WHAT I SHOULD HAVE DONE

Ask: "What CAN'T this platform do?" BEFORE committing.

  • • Platform limitations research: Search "[platform] limitations" or "[platform] can't do"
  • • Read reviews: Users will complain about missing features
  • • Test during trial: Try to do the thing you MIGHT need later
  • • Ask support: "Can I do X?" before committing

💡 Lesson: Every platform has limitations. Smart users discover them BEFORE paying. I discovered Mixo's limitations AFTER paying annual fee. Costly mistake. Always ask "What CAN'T I do?" before committing.

💡 COMMON PLATFORM LIMITATIONS TO WATCH FOR

No code export:

Wix, Squarespace, Mixo, Durable, Pineapple, B12, Bookmark. Can't leave without rebuilding. HUGE limitation.

Weak blog CMS:

Mixo, Durable, basic builders. Fine for 1-5 posts, terrible for 20+ posts or serious content marketing.

No e-commerce:

Many AI builders don't have built-in selling. If you MIGHT sell products, choose platform with e-commerce (Squarespace, Shopify, Framer Commerce).

Limited customization:

Squarespace, Mixo, Durable = template-constrained. If you want custom design beyond templates, choose Webflow or Framer.

Poor SEO tools:

Basic builders have weak SEO. If organic traffic matters, choose WordPress (best SEO) or Squarespace/Framer (decent SEO).

BOTTOM LINE: WHAT I LEARNED

💡 MY BIGGEST LESSONS

Speed is trap. "Generate in 30 seconds" sounds amazing until you outgrow platform in 6 months. Think long-term.

Code export = freedom. Always check before committing. Platforms with export: Framer, Webflow, Relume. Without: Wix, Squarespace, Mixo, Durable.

Test thoroughly. Use free trial to test EVERYTHING, not just homepage. Build full site. Test all features.

Design quality matters. "Good enough" costs more long-term in lost clients. Choose platforms with best design: Framer, Webflow, Squarespace.

Start monthly. Never commit annual until you've tested platform for 2-3 months. That 20% "savings" = trap if platform is wrong.
